results.title: Protectionism (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Monash University, ABC-TV (Australia) and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Global Economy”.
One of the most debated issues for economists is the value of protectionist policies in maintaining and developing national industries. This second episode of the Open Learning economics course examines the pros and cons of protectionism by examining the conflict over trade restrictions placed on sales of US grain to European Community markets. It includes interviews with US business people and with representatives of the French farmers who violently oppossed any easing of European trade restrictions. The second part of the episode explores the various other forms protectionism takes apart from explicit import quotas and taxes. It examines the history of the Voluntary Export Restraint agreement between Japan and the United States which was co-signed in 1981. The agreement offered some protection to an American automobile industry struggling to survive the effects of exploding petroleum prices in the 1970’s. The example delineates the conflict between economic theories which identify people primarily as consumers and those which identify people as labour.

results.title: Trade (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Monash University, ABC-TV (Australia) and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This first episode of the Open Learning economics course examines the changing international relations arising from the increasingly transglobal nature of financial markets. The first part of the episode examines general issues of international trade while the second focuses on the automobile industry in Australia and explores some of the pressures, issues and dynamics involved in restructuring a national industry to maximise competitiveness in international markets.

group_works.title: Ten step discipline program
group_works.creator_credit: William Glasser

results.title: Ten step discipline program
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Help for parents”
Ten step discipline program: Steps 1 to 3 helps teachers use Reality Therapy on themselves. Steps 4 to 6 provide teachers with a simple but effective approach. Steps 7 to 10 consider what procedures can be followed if students refuse to change their behaviour.

results.title: Reality therapy and discipline at home
results.creator_credit: Institute of Reality Therapy, Educator Training Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Help for parents”.
Designed to provide ideas for developing parenting skills to help young people evaluate their behaviour and to plan more acceptable alternatives. Dr William Glasser interviews Tom McGuiness presenting the basic practices used in the Parent Involvement Program at the Institute of Reality Therapy, Educator Training Centre in Los Angeles. Demonstrates how each step is applied in the parent-child relationship.

results.title: Cooking at the Academy
results.creator_credit: Bruce Franchini and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Go behind the scenes of the renowned California Culinary Academy in San Francisco for a taste of a professional cooking school and emerge thinking like a chef! This series gives both novice and experienced cooks an understanding of the how and why of classical cooking techniques.

results.title: Hudson
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, Tasmanian Television and Corporate Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
Football statistics reveal that there has never been a finer spearhead in the history of Australian Rules Football than Peter Hudson. Historical highlights and interviews provide an insight into the game’s most potent offensive player and prolific goal kicking machine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Heazlewood, Tasmanian Television and Corporate Communications

results.title: The Jim Stynes story: Dublin's Jim
results.creator_credit: David Barham and Australian Football Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
In the early ‘80’s the Melbourne Football Club recruited an Irish schoolboy and by the start of the next decade, Jim Stynes had taken the art of ruck play to new levels and won the Brownlow medal.
